description: From Middle English slete, probably from Old English *slēte, *slȳte, *slīete, from Proto-West Germanic *slautijā, from Proto-Germanic *slautijǭ (“sleet”). Walter W. Skeat, the author of Etymological Dictionary of the English Language, suggests Old Norse slydda (whence Danish slud (“mixture of rain and snow”)). The word appears to be akin to Low German Sloot (“hail”), dialectal German Schloße (“large hailstone”), Old Gutnish sloyta (“slush, sleet”).

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) Pellets of ice made of mostly frozen raindrops or refrozen melted snowflakes.
(chiefly UK, Ireland, New England) Precipitation in the form of a mixture of rain and snow.
(rare) A smooth coating of ice formed on ground or other objects by freezing rain.
(firearms) Part of a mortar extending from the chamber to the trunnions.

verbs.description: sleet (third-person singular simple present sleets, present participle sleeting, simple past and past participle sleeted)

entries.meaning: (impersonal, of the weather) To be in a state in which sleet is falling.
examples: I won't bother going out until it's stopped sleeting.
